meanings.def: to move or make something move around a central point
examples: The wheels of the car began to turn.
I can't get the screw to turn.
+ adv./prep. The blades of the helicopter were turning slowly.
turn something I turned the knob and pushed the door open.
turn something + adv./prep. He turned the key in the lock.
She turned the wheel sharply to the left.

meanings.def: to move your body or part of your body so as to face or start moving in a different direction
examples: We turned and headed for home.
turn to do something She turned to look at me.
+ adv./prep. He turned back to his work.
I turned away and looked out of the window.
turn something + adv./prep. He turned his back to the wall.
I turned my face to the sky.
She turned her head away.
turn something I only turned my back for a second.
Lee turned to face her.
While his back was turned (= towards me) I sneaked a look at his notes.

meanings.def: to move something so that it is in a different position or facing a different direction
examples: She turned the chair on its side to repair it.
Turn the sweater inside out before you wash it.

meanings.def: to change the direction you are moving or travelling in; to make something change the direction it is moving in
examples: turn into something He turned into a narrow street.
+ adv./prep. We turned down a dark alleyway.
turn left/right Turn left at the traffic lights.
turn something The man turned the corner and disappeared.
turn something into something I turned the car into the car park.
turn something + adv./prep. The pilot attempted to turn the aircraft towards a wooded area.

meanings.def: to bend or curve in a particular direction
examples: The road turns to the left after the church.
After a while the path turns sharply right.
The river turns north at this point.

meanings.def: if you turn a page of a book or magazine, you move it so that you can read the next page
examples: turn something He sat turning the pages idly.
turn to something Turn to p.23.

meanings.def: to change into a particular state or condition; to make something do this
examples: + adj. The leaves were turning brown.
They say her hair turned white overnight.
I could feel my face turn red with embarrassment.
The weather has turned cold.
He turned nasty when we refused to give him the money.
He decided to turn professional.
turn something + adj. The heat turned the milk sour.
+ noun She turned a deathly shade of white when she heard the news.
He's a lawyer turned politician (= he used to be a lawyer but is now a politician).

meanings.def: to aim or point something in a particular direction
examples: turn something on somebody/something/yourself Police turned water cannon on the rioters.
He turned the gun on himself.
turn something to somebody/something/yourself She looked at him then turned her attention back to me.
turn to somebody/something/yourself His thoughts turned to his dead wife.
Don't turn your anger on the children.
Many supporters are now turning their criticism on the manager.
He tried to forget the events of past few days and turned his thoughts to practical tasks.

meanings.def: to start to come in or go out
examples: The tide is turning—we'd better get back.

meanings.def: to make or let somebody/something go into a particular place or state
examples: turn something + adv./prep. They turned the horse into the field.
turn something + adj. to turn the dogs loose

meanings.def: to fold something in a particular way
examples: She turned down the blankets and climbed into bed.
He turned up the collar of his coat and hurried out into the rain.

meanings.def: to perform a movement by moving your body in a circle
examples: to turn cartwheels/somersaults

meanings.def: if a game turns or somebody turns it, it changes the way it is developing so that a different person or team starts to win
to reach or pass a particular age or time
examples: She turns 21 in June.
It's turned midnight.

meanings.def: when your stomach turns or something turns your stomach, you feel as though you will vomit
to shape something on a lathe
examples: to turn a chair leg
turned boxes and bowls

meanings.def: as was shown or proved by later events
examples: I didn't need my umbrella, as it turned out (= because it didn't rain).

meanings.def: to be well, badly, etc. dressed
likely to be very shocked or angry
examples: My father would turn in his grave if he knew.

meanings.def: used to report what somebody says or does, when this is surprising or annoying
examples: How could she turn round and say that, after all I've done for her?

idioms.def: as was shown or proved by later events
examples: I didn't need my umbrella, as it turned out (= because it didn't rain).

idioms.idiom: be well, badly, etc. turned out
idioms.def: to be well, badly, etc. dressed
likely to be very shocked or angry
examples: My father would turn in his grave if he knew.

idioms.def: used to report what somebody says or does, when this is surprising or annoying
examples: How could she turn round and say that, after all I've done for her?

meanings.def: the time when somebody in a group of people should or is allowed to do something
examples: When it's your turn, take another card.
Please wait your turn.
somebody's turn to do something Whose turn is it to cook?
Steve took a turn driving while I slept.
If you can't put any cards down you have to miss a turn.
By the time it came to my turn to sing, I was a bag of nerves.
Can I have a turn?
Give Sarah a turn on the swing.
I'll take a turn making the dinner—you have a rest.
She had not been friendly to Pete and he, in his turn, was cold to her when she came to stay.

meanings.def: a change in direction in a vehicle
examples: Make a left/right turn into West Street.
turn to the left/right He made a sudden turn to the right.

meanings.def: a place where a road leads away from the one you are travelling on
examples: Take the next turn on the right.
He took a wrong turn and ended up on the coast road.

meanings.def: a bend or corner in a road
examples: a lane full of twists and turns
There was a screech as the car rounded a tight turn.
The car skidded around a hairpin turn.
Slow down as you enter the turn
She stopped talking as she negotiated a particularly sharp turn.

meanings.def: an act of turning somebody/something around
examples: Give the handle a few turns.
The engine started with the first turn of the key.
Rotate the image through a quarter turn.
a full turn of the handle to the right
It slowly spun for three complete turns.
a quick turn of his head
Every time she did a flip turn, she made a large splash.

meanings.def: an unusual or unexpected change in what is happening
examples: a surprising turn of events
His health has taken a turn for the worse (= suddenly got worse).
Events took a dramatic turn in the weeks that followed.
by turns The book is, by turns, funny and very sad.
Her career took an unexpected turn when she moved to New York.
It marks a major turn in this presidency.
He seems to have taken an abrupt career turn with his new movie.
Schuler's life took a radical turn when he became obsessed with horses.
The battle took an unfortunate turn.
The trial has taken an even more bizarre turn today.
The video market took an interesting turn in the mid 1980s.
This movie is by turn terrifying and very funny.
It's impossible to follow all the twists and turns of the plot.

meanings.def: a short performance or piece of entertainment such as a song, etc.
examples: Everyone got up on stage to do a turn.

meanings.def: a short walk
examples: We took a turn around the park.

meanings.def: a feeling of illness
examples: a funny turn (= a feeling that you may faint)
Grandma had one of her turns.

meanings.def: everywhere or every time you try and do something
examples: At every turn I met with disappointment.
Her ideas were blocked at every turn.

meanings.def: cooked for exactly the right amount of time
to frighten or shock somebody
examples: You gave me quite a turn, creeping up on me like that!

meanings.def: (to do) something that helps somebody
examples: Well, that's my good turn for the day.

meanings.def: one after the other in a particular order
examples: The children called out their names in turn.

meanings.def: as a result of something in a series of events
examples: Increased production will, in turn, lead to increased profits.

meanings.def: to do no work
examples: She hasn't done a hand's turn all week.

meanings.def: you should help somebody who has helped you
going to change soon
examples: His luck is on the turn.

meanings.def: if you do something out of turn, you do it when you are not supposed to be the next person to do something
examples: Batista had batted out of turn.
I'm writing to you out of turn because I have some very important news.

meanings.def: to be useful for a particular purpose or period of time
to say something that you should not because it is the wrong situation or because it offends somebody
if people take turns or take it in turns to do something, they do it one after the other to make sure it is done fairly
examples: The male and female birds take turns in sitting on the eggs.
We take it in turns to do the housework.
The kids took turns on the swing.

meanings.def: the time when a new century/year starts
examples: It was built at the turn of the century.
The team are unbeaten since the turn of the year.

meanings.def: a particular way of thinking about things
a particular way of describing something
examples: He is meticulous in his choice of words and turns of phrase.

meanings.def: an extra amount of pressure, cruelty, etc. added to a situation that is already difficult to bear or understand
a sudden increase in your speed or rate of progress; the ability to suddenly increase your speed
examples: He put on an impressive turn of speed in the last lap.
The kangaroo has a fast turn of speed.
For a small car it has a good turn of speed.

idioms.def: everywhere or every time you try and do something
examples: At every turn I met with disappointment.
Her ideas were blocked at every turn.

idioms.def: cooked for exactly the right amount of time
to frighten or shock somebody
examples: You gave me quite a turn, creeping up on me like that!

idioms.def: (to do) something that helps somebody
examples: Well, that's my good turn for the day.

idioms.def: one after the other in a particular order
examples: The children called out their names in turn.
Increased production will, in turn, lead to increased profits.

idioms.def: to do no work
examples: She hasn't done a hand's turn all week.

idioms.def: you should help somebody who has helped you
going to change soon
examples: His luck is on the turn.

idioms.def: if you do something out of turn, you do it when you are not supposed to be the next person to do something
examples: Batista had batted out of turn.
I'm writing to you out of turn because I have some very important news.

idioms.def: to be useful for a particular purpose or period of time
to say something that you should not because it is the wrong situation or because it offends somebody

idioms.idiom: take turns (doing something/in doing something/to do something)
idioms.def: if people take turns or take it in turns to do something, they do it one after the other to make sure it is done fairly
examples: The male and female birds take turns in sitting on the eggs.
We take it in turns to do the housework.
The kids took turns on the swing.

idioms.def: the time when a new century/year starts
examples: It was built at the turn of the century.
The team are unbeaten since the turn of the year.

idioms.def: a particular way of thinking about things
a particular way of describing something
examples: He is meticulous in his choice of words and turns of phrase.

idioms.def: an extra amount of pressure, cruelty, etc. added to a situation that is already difficult to bear or understand
a sudden increase in your speed or rate of progress; the ability to suddenly increase your speed
examples: He put on an impressive turn of speed in the last lap.
The kangaroo has a fast turn of speed.
For a small car it has a good turn of speed.
